item.title: [317] Got any ways i can Protect my server?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“imsuperman05, post:23, topic:427938”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=530626.msg3875996#msg3875996 date=1325686257]

There is nothing, absolutely nothing, you can do in or with the client to protect your server. When writing a public server, you can NEVER trust the client. So basically don’t listen to most of the things these people are telling you, and make sure that on your server, you verify that every bit of information the client sends to you is perfectly valid before acting on it.

At first I thought this was a bit of a troll, then I understood. But see if the client doesn’t comply with the standards of the server, such as with the RSA verification, then it would be impossible to login. Of course there is nothing that will totally stop it but you can always help prevent it.

But there is nothing stopping someone from modifying your client to do what they want (yes, even if you ‘set a uid’), so no matter what, you can never trust the client.
[/quote]
What if I renamed all the files, then deleted the java files?[/quote]

They can decompile it probably, and even if they can’t, they can still do all sorts of things to it to send false information to your server. You can NEVER trust the client, it’s the basic principle behind all client-server programming everywhere.

[quote=“Team_Rocket, post:25, topic:427938”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=530626.msg3875996#msg3875996 date=1325686257]

There is nothing, absolutely nothing, you can do in or with the client to protect your server. When writing a public server, you can NEVER trust the client. So basically don’t listen to most of the things these people are telling you, and make sure that on your server, you verify that every bit of information the client sends to you is perfectly valid before acting on it.

At first I thought this was a bit of a troll, then I understood. But see if the client doesn’t comply with the standards of the server, such as with the RSA verification, then it would be impossible to login. Of course there is nothing that will totally stop it but you can always help prevent it.

But there is nothing stopping someone from modifying your client to do what they want (yes, even if you ‘set a uid’), so no matter what, you can never trust the client.
[/quote]

This is why I’d always use a web-client.[/quote]

How does that stop anything at all? Jagex only uses a web-client, and that worked out well for them, didn’t it?

item.title: [317] Got any ways i can Protect my server?
item.dc:creator: @Team_Rocket Team_Rocket
item.description:
@Team_Rocket wrote:

[quote=“imsuperman05, post:26, topic:427938”][quote author=Team_Rocket link=topic=530626.msg3876017#msg3876017 date=1325688687]

There is nothing, absolutely nothing, you can do in or with the client to protect your server. When writing a public server, you can NEVER trust the client. So basically don’t listen to most of the things these people are telling you, and make sure that on your server, you verify that every bit of information the client sends to you is perfectly valid before acting on it.

At first I thought this was a bit of a troll, then I understood. But see if the client doesn’t comply with the standards of the server, such as with the RSA verification, then it would be impossible to login. Of course there is nothing that will totally stop it but you can always help prevent it.

But there is nothing stopping someone from modifying your client to do what they want (yes, even if you ‘set a uid’), so no matter what, you can never trust the client.

This is why I’d always use a web-client.

EDIT:

@imsuperman05

You can easily decompile classes.
[/quote]
But you can’t modify the files because decompilers aren’t 100%, and will give back some errors.

Even if you use a webclient, I can right click on page “View page source,” and search for .jar.[/quote]

I’ve heard of this, but every-time I’ve decompiled it always got all of the content. I’ve never had any trouble out of “reverse engineering” with clients. I’m not talking about decompiling a .Jar by the way.
